post_text: Link’s teachers and staff have been working hard for the past two+ weeks to get ready for the start of the new school year. They have been busy refreshing themselves on the platforms and practices they used successfully in the spring and summer for remote learning – improving upon them and discovering even more ways to deliver engaging content remotely. ELA and math teachers attended “boot camp” with the respective area coaches to strengthen their teaching. Everyone participated in professional development around student discipline strategy, cultural awareness/diversity, and much more. All of this was done virtually! A huge amount of time and effort spent by Link’s amazing, dedicated teachers and staff to make this the best year possible for our scholars…they deserve it. #linkteacherscare #linkstaffrocks #linkteachersrock #LinkStronG

post_text: Congratulations to Hannah-Marie Kennedy, Link’s history teacher and school culture leader, for receiving a New Jersey Teacher Leader Fellowship from JerseyCAN! She will be one of ten teachers (out of over 700 applicants) to gain knowledge and experience in advocating for education and the teaching profession. Fellows explore and discuss the most recent education policies and issues in an eight month program, held outside the workday, preparing them to be leaders in policy making in the future. A lifelong learner, Mrs. Kennedy is excited about the fellowship, seeing it as a way to further develop her ability to impact equity in education. Way to go, Mrs. Kennedy; Link is proud of you! #linkteachersrock #linkachieves

post_text: Link’s 6th, 7th, and 8th grade scholars attended a performance of Liner Notes at New Jersey Performing Arts Center (NJPAC) last Thursday in celebration of Black History Month. post_text: Our 8th graders watched the movie Just Mercy at the CityPlex Newark this week as part of Black History Month activities. The movie is based on the memoir of Bryan Stevenson, an African American Harvard University trained attorney who works to reverse wrongful convictions for minorities, the poor and children, in particular death sentences, in Alabama. He founded the Equal Justice Initiative, a nonprofit to continue his work. The movie’s focus is on one of Mr. Stevenson’s cases. After the poignant movie, students visited Rutgers Law School and met the Dean of the Law School in the Mock Courtroom and had small group discussions about the movie. The movie appeared to impact the students greatly, as evidenced by their discussion. #linkerslearn #socialjustice #justmercy #BHM #EJI #equaljustice

#LINKALUMNI OPPORTUNITY ALERT:

Apply by DECEMBER 27, 2019 to the Leadership Newark (LN) Junior Fellowship Program (JFP) if you are:
✅ Interested in civic engagement and activism
✅ Passionate about having a voice in improving your community
✅ A current high school student
✅ A current Newark resident

A festive opening to the 2019-2020 school year! Link launched its yearlong celebration of the school’s 50 anniversary today. Link students set sail on the Passaic River last Saturday in a boat – the “S.S. Lit.’ – that they built themselves! Under the guidance of Ms. Jen Reich and Ms. Ashaki Charles (Link Class of 2012) from Project U.S.E.- Urban Suburban Environments, scholars spent an estimated 16 hours working on the boat during elective class over the course of two quarters.

The launch took place at Riverfront Park in the Ironbound Section of Newark. Students explained their work to the community present, which included participants from Covenant House and Queen City Academy Charter School, telling everyone how they constructed and painted the boat. Scholars then showed off their strong teamwork skills - and strong arms! - paddling through the river, working against a strong current. The Link community was proudly represented by this group! And all were happy that the boat remained afloat! #boatbuilding #newarknj

DESIGN & PAINT A CATCH BASIN!!!!
Link has partnered with the Newark Office of Sustainability in the “Adopt a Catch Basin” project, designed to help reduce the amount of litter and debris getting into city pipes and local waterways and to beautify neighborhoods. Link has adopted several catch basins in the area around the school, and students and alumni will have the chance to design and paint the basins, and then work to maintain them to keep rivers free of debris, create healthier a healthier habitat for fish, and lessen street flooding in Newark.

So, we need your help! We know there are amazing artists within Link's alumni network. We would be honored to showcase your talents to make our great city of Newark safer, cleaner, greener, and more beautiful.

Become a part of the fabric and history of Newark! Click here for more information and to submit your designs by May 1st : http://www.linkschool.org/call-for-link-alumni-art-design-submissions/
